grc.header.tooltip: A core service that enables operators to define multicluster policies needed to meet enterprise requirements and standards.
grc.remediation.tooltip: Some policy controllers might not support the enforce feature. If the enforce feature is not supported by the controller, you must remediate it manually.
policy.create.tooltip: Creates a resource that generates reports and validates cluster compliance based on your specified security standards, categories, and controls.
policy.create.namespace.tooltip: The namespace to create and store the policy on the hub cluster.
policy.create.specs.tooltip: The parameter section that describes which set of rules will validate a cluster.
policy.create.selectors.tooltip: Fill the required parameter field to select the cluster where your policy is applied. The placement policy and placement binding are required, and added into the YAML file.
policy.create.remediation.tooltip: Represents how violations are handled as defined in the resource.
policy.create.standards.tooltip: The name or names of security standards your policy should validate. You can only create a new label by adding it directly into the YAML file.
policy.create.categories.tooltip: A security control category represent specific requirements for one or more standards. You can only create a new label by adding it directly into the YAML file.
policy.create.controls.tooltip: The control contains the instructions for ensuring that a policy meets the security requirements for one or more standards. You can only create a new label by adding it directly into the YAML file.
policy.create.disabled.tooltip: Select to disable the policy from being propagated to the managed cluster. If selected, the policy can be re-enabled from the dropdown menu in the policies table.
policy.disabled.label: disabled

welcome.label: Welcome to Red Hat Advanced Cluster Management for Kubernetes
welcome.paragraph.description: Red Hat Advanced Cluster Management for Kubernetes provides the tools and capabilities to address various challenges with managing multiple clusters and consoles, distributed business applications, and inconsistent security controls across Kubernetes clusters that are deployed on-premises, or across public clouds.
welcome.connect.label: Information on how to connect with Red Hat Advanced Cluster Management for Kubernetes
welcome.card.one.title: End-to-end visibility
welcome.card.one.desc: View system alerts, critical application metrics, and overall system health. Search, identify, and resolve issues that are impacting distributed workloads using an operational dashboard designed for Site Reliability Engineers (SREs).
welcome.card.two.title: Cluster lifecycle
welcome.card.two.desc: Create, update, scale, and remove clusters reliably, consistently using an open source programming model that supports and encourages Infrastructure as Code best practices and design principles.
welcome.card.three.title: Application lifecycle
welcome.card.three.desc: Define a business application using open standards and deploy the applications using placement policies that are integrated into existing CI/CD pipelines and governance controls.
welcome.card.four.title: Governance, Risk, and Compliance
welcome.card.four.desc: Use policies to automatically configure and maintain consistency of security controls required by industry or other corporate standards. Prevent unintentional or malicious configuration drift that might expose unwanted and unnecessary threat vectors.
welcome.information.heading: Easy, simple, and secure.
welcome.information.top: Easy to use and simple to understand, Red Hat Advanced Cluster Management for Kubernetes provides the following mission critical capabilities based on open source projects:
welcome.information.items.kubernetes.des: Easily provision Kubernetes clusters and offer complete cluster lifecycle management in a single console.
welcome.information.items.policies.title: Policies
welcome.information.items.policies.desc: Enforce policies at the target clusters using Kubernetes-supported custom resource definitions.
welcome.information.items.landscape.desc: Deploy and maintain day two operations of applications distributed across your cluster landscape.
welcome.information.items.envs.title: Range of environments
welcome.information.items.envs.desc: Work across a range of environments, including multiple data centers, and private and public clouds.
welcome.information.items.integration.de: Quickly view service endpoints, pods, and dependant resources that comprise your application topology.
welcome.information.items.alerts.title: Cluster labels and placement rules
welcome.information.items.alerts.desc: Use cluster labels and application placement rules to easily move workloads across clusters, even between multiple cloud providers.
welcome.connect.heading: Converse and connect.
welcome.connect.box.one.title.two: Want more information? Check out the developer community.
welcome.connect.box.two.title.two: Join our Slack community to connect and chat with us.
